title.value: A NEURONAL LEAST-ACTION PRINCIPLE FOR REAL-TIME LEARNING IN CORTICAL CIRCUITS
title.justification: This title is prominent at the beginning of the paper and encompasses the main subject of the research.
title.quote: A NEURONAL LEAST-ACTION PRINCIPLE FOR REAL - TIME LEARNING IN CORTICAL CIRCUITS

extractions.description: The paper introduces a neural least-action principle aimed at minimizing somato-dendritic mismatch errors in cortical networks. It applies this principle to real-time learning in motor control by prospective error correction dynamics and synaptic plasticity.

type.justification: The study primarily discusses theoretical frameworks and principles for understanding neuronal and synaptic dynamics.
type.quote: The present paper formalizes this principle and reformulates the classical equilibrium point hypothesis (Latash, 2010) in a dynamical setting.

name.justification: The paper discusses neural dynamics, cortical circuits, and synaptic processing.
name.quote: We introduce a neural least-action principle that we apply to motor control.

name.justification: The study employs computational models to explain neuronal dynamics.
name.quote: Our theory considers the minimization of a mismatch between the effective output trajectory and an internally or externally imposed target trajectory.

name.justification: The research is specifically applied to motor control through the introduced principle.
name.quote: We introduce a neural least-action principle that we apply to motor control.

name.justification: The NLA Principle is introduced as the main framework used for understanding real-time learning in the study.
name.quote: The principle postulates that the somato-dendritic mismatch errors across all neurons in a cortical network are minimized by the voltage dynamics.
